clinical_study.brief_title: Intervention Based on Implicit Theories of Personality: Effects on Depression and Bullying
clinical_study.official_title: Prevention of Depression and Bullying in Adolescents by Means of an Intervention Based on Implicit Theories of Personality

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates the efficacy of an intervention based on the Implicit Theories of Personality (ITP) in Spanish adolescents. Half of participants received the ITP intervention, while the other half received an educational intervention.

detailed_description.textblock: Depression and bullying are two problems arising in childhood and adolescence, which cause severe suffering. Although there are good intervention programs for children and adolescents at risk, the results for universal interventions have generally been poor. The current project will test the efficacy of an Intervention based on the Implicit Theories of Personality (ITP). This procedure has recently been developed at US by David S. Yeager and colleagues, with extraordinary results in the reduction of depression, stress, and aggression. The project includes the following aims: (1) the evaluation of the efficacy of the ITP in Spanish adolescents; (2) the identification of the mechanisms mediating the effects of ITP in depression and bullying (these mediators include changes in cognitive vulnerabilities and hormones -cortisol, testosterone and DHEA in saliva); (3) the identification of moderators of the effects of the ITP, such as age, early family experiences, temperament and gender; and (4) the inclusion of a transactional perspective in order to determine whether the ITP changes the reciprocal longitudinal paths between risk factors, environmental stressors, cognitive vulnerabilities, and depressive symptoms and aggressive behavior; The study involves the evaluation of the intervention in a sample of around 1000 adolescents (12-18 years), randomly allocated to experimental and control condition. It is a field experiment conducted in high schools and involves multiple measures over time (self-reports and parent reports; as well as levels of cortisol, testosterone and DHEA in saliva in random subset -60%- of the participants). In summary, the project aims to respond to the challenge of health and wellness in the population through a randomized controlled trial with multiple sources of measure and from a biopsychosocial perspective. The ITP intervention has the potential to become a universal intervention to help reduce the rates of depression and bullying.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants were randomized in a 1:1 ratio blocked by gender to one of two groups: experimental condition (ITP intervention) versus control condition (educational intervention) in parallel for the duration of the study.
study_design_info.masking_description: Allocation was concealed to the participants, researchers -who were in class the assessment days- and teachers.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline scores of the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression scale (CES-D; Radloff, 1977) at 2 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Self reported depressive symptoms during the last month (last week in the 1 week follow-up) measured by 20 items scored 0-3 (0 = rarely; 3 = most or almost all the time), yielding a total between 0 and 60.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline scores of the Revised version of the Peer Experiences Questionnaire (RPEQ; Prinstein, Boergers, & Vernberg, 2001) at 2 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Self reported levels of victimization (9 items) and perpetration (9 items) of peer aggression in the school context during the last 6 months (last week in the 1 week follow-up). Each item is scored 1-5 (1 = never; 5 = several times per week), yielding a total between 18 and 90.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline scores of the Cyber Bullying Questionnaire (CBQ; Calvete et al., 2012; Gámez-Guadix, Villa-George, & Calvete, 2014) at 2 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: Self reported levels of victimization (9 items) and perpetration (9 items) of peer cyber aggression during the last 6 months (last week in the 1 week follow-up). Each item is scored 0-3 (0 = never; 3 = five or more times), yielding a total between 0 and 54.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline levels of Cortisol, DHEA and testosterone (in saliva) at 2 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months.
primary_outcome.description: A random subset of the participants (n = 546) have provided saliva samples to be assayed for neuroendocrine levels to measure cortisol, DHEA and testosterone. They were directed to transfer saliva from their mouths to a tube. The sample tubes were carefully labelled, and as soon as the session ended, saliva samples were sent to the assay laboratory (Medikosta IMQ Análisis Clínicos) and stored in a freezer at -80°C.

secondary_outcome.measure: Short version of the Adolescent Life Events Questionnaire (ALEQ; Hankin & Abramson, 2002)
secondary_outcome.description: Self reported negative life events during the last 6 months measured by 24 items (one event each item). Participants indicate whether these negative events have occurred to them, and if so, the degree of stress they felt ranging 0-3 (0 = not at all stressful; 3 = very stressful), yielding a total between 0 and 72.

secondary_outcome.measure: Implicit Theories of Personality questionnaire (Yeager et al., 2014)
secondary_outcome.description: Self reported measure that assesses adolescents' implicit theories of personality during the last 6 months (last week in the 1 week follow-up) measured by 8 items scored 1-6 (1 = strongly disagree; 6 = strongly agree), yielding a total between 8 and 48.

Self reported maladaptive cognitive schemas during the last 6 months (last week in the 1 week follow-up). The original version has 90 items, but for the purposes of this study, we have included 35 items of 7 subscales: defectiveness/shame (5 items), mistrust/abuse (5 items), entitlement superiority/grandiosity (5 items), failure to achieve (5 items), insufficient self control/self discipline (5 items), abandonment/instability (5 items), emotional deprivation (deprivación). Each item is scored 1-6 (1 = strongly disagree; 6 = strongly agree), yielding a total between 5 and 30 for each subscale.

secondary_outcome.measure: Adolescents Cognitive Style Questionnaire (ACSQ; Abramson et al., 1989)
secondary_outcome.description: Self-reported questionnaire that assesses cognitive vulnerability, including negative inferences about the causes of negative events, their consequences, and their implications for the self. The questionnaire presents 12 hypothetical negative scenarios (6 of an interpersonal nature and 6 related to achievement or performance) that are relevant in adolescence. Adolescents are requested to imagine each scenario and rate in a Likert type 7 point scale the extent to which they believe that the cause of the event is internal, stable, and global (attribution of causes), the likelihood that future negative consequences of the event will occur (inferences about consequences), and the extent to which they believe that what happened shows that they failed as individuals (inferences about the self). The response scale ranges from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree), with higher values indicating that the adolescent displays a hopeless cognitive style.

secondary_outcome.measure: Subscale of brooding rumination of the Children's Response Styles Scale (CRSS; Ziegert and Kistner, 2002)
secondary_outcome.description: Self reported ruminative responses to sad mood in adolescence. Participants need to indicate the frequency with they engage in each particular situation described in the 5 items when they feel sad. Each item is scored 1-4 (1 = almost never; 3 = almost always), yielding a total between 5 and 20.

secondary_outcome.measure: Big Five Questionnaire for children (BFQ-C; Barbaranelli et al., 2003)
secondary_outcome.description: Self reported questionnaire that assesses five personality traits: openness to experience, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism. For the purpose of this study, we have used the 21 items from the extraversion and neuroticism subscales. Each item is scored 1-5 (1 =almost always untrue of you ; 5 = almost always true of you).

secondary_outcome.measure: Revised version of the Early Adolescent Temperament Questionnaire (EATQ-R; Ellis and Rothbart, 2001)
secondary_outcome.description: Self reported questionnaire of that assesses temperament in adolescents. For this study, only the 10 items of the temperament domain of effortful control were used, which measure self-regulation aspects of temperament in adolescents with three subscales: inhibition control, attention and activation control. Each item is scored 1-5 (1 =almost always untrue of you ; 5 = almost always true of you), yielding a total between 1 and 50.

secondary_outcome.measure: Affection and Communication subscale of the Parenting Style Scale (Oliva, Parra, Sanchez-Queija, & López, 2007).
secondary_outcome.description: 8 items for each parent (referred to the mother and to the father) from the affection and communication subscale, which assesses support and care delivered by the parents, their ability to be there, and the communication between them. Each item is scored 1-6 (1= not at all true to 6=completely true), yielding a total between 8 and 48.

other_outcome.measure: Child Behavior Checklist for ages 6-18 (CBCL/6-18; Achenbach & Rescorla, 2001)
other_outcome.description: The CBCL is a questionnaire for obtaining parents' reports of their child's competencies and problems. In order to examine children depressive symptoms 9 items from the subscales of: withdrawn/depressed, anxious/depressed, thought problems and somatic problems were used. Each item is scored 0-2 (0 = it is not true; 2 = quite/very often), yielding a total between 0 18.

other_outcome.measure: Short version of the Adolescent Life Events Questionnaire (ALEQ) for parents
other_outcome.description: An ad hoc cheklist of negative life events (24 items: one event each item) during the last 6 months reported by adolescents' parents. Parents indicate whether these negative events have occurred to their children (0 = no; 1 = yes), yielding a total between 0 and 24.

other_outcome.measure: Big Five Questionnaire for children (BFQ-C) for parents (Barbaranelli et al., 2003)
other_outcome.description: 21 items from the BFQ-C that assess the extraversion and neuroticism reported by the adolescents' parents. Each item is scored 1-5 (1 =almost never ; 5 = almost always).

other_outcome.measure: Revised version of the Early Adolescent Temperament Questionnaire (EATQ-R) for parents (Ellis and Rothbart, 2001)
other_outcome.description: 10 items of the temperament domain of effortful control of the EATQ-R reported by the adolescents' parents. Each item is scored 1-5 (1 =almost never ; 5 = almost always), yielding a total between 1 and 50.

other_outcome.measure: Affection and Communication subscale of the Parenting Style Scale (Oliva, Parra, Sanchez-Queija, & López, 2007) for parents.
other_outcome.description: 8 items reported by the adolescents' parents from the affection and communication subscale, which assesses support and care delivered by the parents, their ability to be there, and the communication between them. Each item is scored 1-6 (1= not at all true to 6=completely true), yielding a total between 8 and 48.

arm_group.description: 1 hour behavioral intervention (based on ITP) consisting on several tasks to be completed on paper individually.
1 hour educational intervention (about the human brain) consisting on several tasks to be completed on paper individually.

intervention.description: The experimental intervention (originally developed by David S. Yeager and colleagues) teaches that individuals have the potential to change. It has three main parts. First, participants are asked to read scientific studies that provide evidence that behaviors are controlled by "thoughts and feelings in brains," and that pathways in the brain have the potential to be changed under the right circumstances. Second, participants read several testimonials purportedly written by upperclassmen to bring credibility to the ITP. Finally, participants are asked to write their own version of such a narrative. This self-persuasive writing exercise has been shown to facilitate the internalization of the intervention message, building on a long line of research on cognitive dissonance.

The educational intervention involved scientific information about the human brain. It was designed to be parallel to the experimental intervention and, hence, it has also three main parts. First, participants are asked to read scientific information about the different areas of the brain and their specialties. Second, participants read several testimonials written by upperclassmen about their transition to high school and how their brains help them to adapt to the new space and all the physical differences of the building and the classes. Finally, participants are asked to write a letter to another student explaining the main things he or she has learned about the brain and thinks are important for adapting to the new physical environment in high school.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Informed consent by the adolescents and their parents.
- To be fluent in Spanish.

patient_data.ipd_description: Individual participant data will be provided to the journals in which it is planned to publish the results of the study. In addition, the PI and research team will consider to make IPD available to other researchers after publishing the results of the study.
